title.value: Data-access performance anti-patterns in data-intensive systems
title.justification: The title is stated clearly at the beginning and throughout the paper.
title.quote:
Data-access performance anti-patterns in
data-intensive systems

extractions.description: This paper investigates data-access performance anti-patterns in NoSQL-based and polyglot persistence data-intensive systems. It aims to identify, categorize, and validate these issues using a qualitative study on issues reported in open source projects and a developer survey.

type.justification: The study involves collecting and analyzing data from real-world open-source projects and conducting surveys with developers.
type.quote: The goal of this empirical study is to specify data-access performance anti-patterns by conducting a qualitative analy-sis of issues collected from the repositories of 75 NoSQL-based and 87 polyglot persistence open-source data-intensive systems, and evaluating the perceived relevance of the perfor-mance anti-patterns by developers of industrial data-intensive systems.

name.justification: The paper focuses on performance issues within data access code for data-intensive systems, which is a part of software engineering.
name.quote: Data-access is a critical component of data-intensive systems as it determines the overall performance and functionality of such systems.

name.justification: The study involves analyzing performance issues in data-intensive systems, which primarily involve databases.
name.quote: Identify, categorize, and validate data access per-formance issues in the context of NoSQL-based and polyglot persistence data-intensive systems using qualitative study.

name.justification: The study focuses on performance anti-patterns which impact the performance of data-intensive systems.
name.quote: We investigate data access performance issues using data from issues reported by the end users of NoSQL-based and polyglot persistence data-intensive systems.

name.value: NoSQL and Polyglot Persistence System Issues Dataset
name.justification: The study collected issues from 75 NoSQL-based and 87 polyglot persistence open-source data-intensive systems.
name.quote: For each of the 162 subject systems, we collected all issues from their GitHub repositories using PyGithub.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Although the dataset is utilized for analysis in this study, it is implicated as constructed by the researchers for this specific research purpose rather than obtained from previously published references.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For each of the 162 subject systems, we collected all issues from their GitHub repositories using PyGithub.

name.justification: PyGithub is mentioned as a tool used for collecting data from GitHub.
name.quote: we collected all issues from their GitHub repositories using PyGithub.

referenced_paper_title.justification: PyGithub, a library for GitHub API access, is utilized in the study to gather the dataset, but the paper does not reference a specific source paper for this library.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Since we want to investigate the solutions proposed to mitigate the issues, we are only interested in closed issues. We collected a total of 526672 closed issues from NoSQL based systems and 257840 closed issues from the polyglot persistence-based systems and stored them in the Elasticsearch database.
